review_title: The miserly pay is not worth the misery of working in this joyless, soul-crushing office.
pros: If you are looking for a job where daily unnecessary, rambling meetings are the norm for issues that could be resolved by a simple email, then this is the place for you! Decent benefits but hardly worth the headache.
cons:
Manager was either ignorant or dismissive of even the most basic laws dictating patient confidentiality and transmission of patient information (HIPAA). Manager was absolutely clueless when it came to utilizing current software and Excel products to collate/disseminate data, which would have made the team more efficient and even streamlined. Manager was intimidated when staff had a skill or experience outside of their own skill set and as such, retaliated against the offending staff. A favorite saying in the office was, "this is how we've always done it" and that mindset was fostered rather than challenged.  Management had no interest whatsoever in becoming better, fostering positive relationships, fixing existing problems or educating staff beyond proper work uniform and attendance guidelines . To say it was a toxic work environment is an understatement. Good luck trying to make a positive, meaningful difference as an employee.

Also, pay raises are directly tied to employee satisfaction thus if you are honest and rate your department's metrics appropriately,  YOU are punished for YOUR dissatisfaction via an already laughable wage increase. This is one particularly cruel method by which management silences dissent.

pros: Challenging but rewarding with strong patient focus and committed to the underserved and disadvantaged. Committed advocates! J2E has provided good support and has helped build a good foundation.
cons: Leaders sometimes treat and talk about staff as if they are children; HR needs to relax their time clock requirements like 8:01 is tardy...contributing to already stressed employees. Coaching of staff often rigid and overdone. Respect and give a little more flexability with staff could help retention and recruitment--we need to recognize nurses and others as professionals. Extending education commitment to allowing staff two days of education yearly without using PTO. Amount of PTOs does not allow for an appropriate work life balance...there is a lot of unrecognized burnout. Our employees are only as good as the leaders engage and RESPECT them. Let's prevent burnout and maintain safe environments for patient care

review_title: Good culture (for the most part), bad compensation
pros: Good clinical experience, many managers really believe in promoting good employee culture, generally most employees believe in putting the patients first. I liked the employee forums, where leadership would essentially communicate to employees what was going on on an administrative level. Coin cards were always a nice surprise and encouraging to read. Also liked getting thank you cards from management, which helped me feel noticed and appreciated.
cons: Human Resources. Let me just say, first off, I consider myself a fair person - I fully understand that one should get paid based on experience, current position, and the market average that matches those two things. No one is expecting big $$ at a nonprofit hospital. I also understand that virtually every employee at any company on glassdoor is going to claim they are not being paid enough. That being said, the pay with LGH is genuinely atrocious, although they continually claim that it is comparable to market value. I can assure you, it is not even close. I almost made more money working part time for another company than I did working full time for LGH.  If you want great clinical experience and don't mind penny pinching for a few years, LGH is great. However, if you are seasoned, have kids in college, or have a mortgage, look elsewhere.
